verb.description: (especially of a pipe, a vessel, or a bodily part such as an organ or membrane) break or burst suddenly.
examples: if the main artery ruptures he could die

verb.description: Breach or disturb (a harmonious feeling or situation)
examples: once trust has been ruptured it can be difficult to regain

noun.description: An instance of breaking or bursting suddenly and completely.
examples: a small hairline crack could develop into a rupture
the patient died after rupture of an aneurysm

noun.description: A breach of a harmonious relationship.
examples: the rupture with his father would never be healed

origin: Late Middle English (as a noun): from Old French rupture or Latin ruptura, from rumpere to break. The verb dates from the mid 18th century.
